affiliation.orgName: Decentralized Adaptive Fuzzy Secure Control for Nonlinear Uncertain Interconnected Systems Against Intermittent DoS Attacks

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Cyber-physical systems (CPSs) are naturally highly interconnected and complexly nonlinear. This paper investigates the problem of decentralized adaptive output feedback control for CPSs subject to intermittent denial-of-service (DoS) attacks. The considered CPSs are modeled as a class of nonlinear uncertain strict-feedback interconnected systems. When a DoS attack is active, all the state variables become unavailable and standard backstepping cannot be applied. To overcome this difficulty, a switching-type adaptive state estimator is constructed. Based on an improved average dwell time method incorporated by frequency and duration properties of DoS attacks, convex design conditions of controller parameters are derived in term of solving a set of linear matrix inequalities. The proposed controller guarantees that all closed-loop signals remain bounded, while the error signals converge to a small neighborhood of the origin. As an illustrative example, the proposed control scheme is applied to a power network system.

transportation systems [2], [3]. However, due to the introduction of embedded networked control technique, CPSs become also more vulnerable for cyber attacks. Thus, the security of CPSs has recently become one of the research hotspots in control field.

Deception attacks and denial-of-service (DoS) attacks are one of the main concerns of CPSs security. The goal of deception attacks is to tamper transmitted information resulting in false or misleading feedback data [6], [7], which includes some typical attack models such as replay attack [4] and false data injection attack [5], [9]. Compared to these deception attacks, the DoS attacks, which attempt to block the information transmission between system devices or components, are easier to be launched for adversaries and more reachable in the attack space [10]. Recently, researchers have investigated the DoS attacks from two opposite standpoints, i.e., how to attack and how to defense. From the viewpoint of the attack, in [16] and [17], the optimal DoS attack schedules are designed with energy constraint, which illustrate that the optimal DoS attack sequences should be in a consecutive form. On the opposite standpoint, in [8], [11], and [12], the resilient control problem is considered for linear and nonlinear systems, respectively, where the frequency and duration are introduced to characterize energy constraint of the DoS attacks. In [15], the optimal controller is constructed to counter an intelligent jammer with limited action. However, the most existing results mainly focus on investigating the centralized control against DoS attacks for linear or nonlinear systems with completely known model knowledge. There has been little theoretical work appeared on decentralized control for the uncertain interconnected CPSs under DoS attacks.

Over the past decades, adaptive control of nonlinear uncertain systems has been widely studied [18]- [24]. The main ideal is to control systems with uncertainties by estimating online unknown system parameters. In particular, for nonlinear strictfeedback systems, the celebrated backstepping-based adaptive approach is a powerful tool for controller design. Note that in practice, many CPSs can be modeled into a strict-feedback form, such as power network systems [6], [40]. Meanwhile, fuzzy control has been also applied to some nonlinear network systems [25], [26]. Decentralized fuzzy adaptive control for uncertain interconnected systems has long received a lot of attention in the control field due to its both theoretical and practical importance, and many fuzzy or neural-network adaptive backstepping methods have also been generalized to 2168-2267 c 2018 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission.
See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information.

large-scale interconnected systems [20]- [23]. To the best of our knowledge, the majority of the literature on adaptive backstepping control strategies do not address cyber-security issues like the counteraction problem of DoS attacks. However, there are two main difficulties to be addressed. 1) How to estimate the system state in the presence of intermittent DoS attacks which make all system states become unavailable? 2) How to establish the Lyapunov function analysis on active and sleeping intervals of the DoS attack in the presence of nonlinear uncertainties, respectively? Therefore, it is highly desired to develop an observer-based adaptive backstepping secure control scheme against intermittent DoS attacks.

Motivated by these observations, this paper investigates the problem of output-based resilient control for a class of nonlinear uncertain interconnected systems subject to DoS attacks and external disturbances. The considered systems are modeled into a strict-feedback form under continuous-time settings, and the DoS attack model is assumed to be intermittent in terms of its constrained frequency and duration [13]. The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows.

1) This paper proposes a novel decentralized adaptive control methodology, which guarantees that, even in the presence of the DoS attacks, all the signals of the closedloop systems remain bounded, while the error signals converge to a small neighborhood of the origin. 2) To overcome the difficulty that all the state variables are unavailable when a DoS attack is active, a switchingtype state estimator is constructed to obtain the system state by using discontinuous output measurement. 3) Both convergence and divergence conditions of the Lyapunov function on sleeping and active intervals of the DoS attack are guaranteed by solving a set of linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). 4) The classical average dwell time (ADT) method in [27] and [37] cannot be applied directly since the overall system is switched between stable subsystem (when the attacker is sleeping) and unstable subsystem (when the attacker is active). In order to solve this problem under study, the classical ADT method is improved by incorporating the unstable duration concept. The remaining structure of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we describe the system and attack models. Decentralized adaptive secure control scheme and stability analysis are given in Section III. In Section IV, a two-machine power system is simulated, and finally we conclude the work of this paper in Section V.

div.head: A. System Descriptions and Assumptions
div.p: Consider a class of interconnected nonlinear CPSs in strictfeedback form, which is composed of N subsystems. The ith subsystem is given as follows:
div.formula: ẋi,j = f i,j xi,j + x i,j+1 + i,j (ȳ) + d i,j (t)

div.head: ẋi,n
div.formula: i = f i,n i xi,n i + u i + i,n i (ȳ) + d i,n i (t) y i = x i,1 , i = 1, . . . , N, j = 1, . . . , n i -1 (1)
div.p: where xi,j = [x i,1 , . . . , x i,j ] T ∈ R j , u i ∈ R, and y i ∈ R are unmeasurable states, control inputs, and system outputs, respectively, f i,j (•) and f i,n i (•) are unknown smooth functions, i,j (ȳ) and i,n i (ȳ) denote uncertain interactions among subsystems with ȳ = [y 1 , . . . , y N ], and d i,j and d i,n i are the external disturbances satisfying |d i,j | ≤ di,j and |d i,n i | ≤ di,n i with di,j and di,n i being unknown positive constants.

Remark 1: A typical CPS with the strict-feedback form as model ( 1) is the power network system. Many important works on the security of the power network systems have been developed, such as attack detection and identification [6] and robust and resilient control [28]. In this paper, the power system with model uncertainties and nonlinear interconnections is further studied.
To satisfy the desired control goals, some common assumptions are necessary for system (1).
Assumption 1: For functions f i,j , i = 1, . . . , N, j = 1, . . . , n i , there exist some known constants m i,j , such that ∀X 1 , X 2 , the following inequality holds:
div.formula: f i,j (X 1 ) -f i,j (X 2 ) ≤ m i,j X 1 -X 2
div.p: where X denotes the two-norm of a vector X.
Assumption 2: There exist a known smooth positive function
div.formula: ijk (•) satisfying ijk (0) = 0 and a constant ij > 0 such that 2 i,j (ȳ) ≤ N k=1 ijk (x k,1 ) + ij .
div.p: Remark 2: Assumption 1 is common in the study of output feedback controller design for nonlinear strict-feedback system [18], [20]. Assumption 2 is also reasonable according to separation technique [32]. Further, since ijk (0) = 0, then there exists a smooth function h ijk (x k,1 ) such that ijk (x k,1 ) = x k,1 h ijk (x k,1 ), and further assume there exists a constant l h ijk such that
div.formula: |h ijk (X 1 ) -h ijk (X 2 )| ≤ l h ijk |X 1 -X 2 | for any X 1 , X 2 ∈ R.

div.head: B. Intermittent DoS Attack Model
div.p: In practice, the sensors measure the output signal ȳ(t) and sends it to a remote estimator via a wireless networked channel. The adversaries attempt to jam the communication channel to destroy the stability of system (see Fig. 1). Due to the energy constraint of adversaries [16], [17], or several provisions such as spreading techniques and high-pass filtering to mitigate DoS attacks [29], [30], the DoS attacks usually arrive in an intermittent or random manner [31]. In this paper, we consider the case that the intermittent DoS attack is performed by the attacker. This amounts to that one adversary can only launch the DoS attack discontinuously. Using the method [11], let {t j } j∈N , where t 0 ≥ 0, represent the time instants when the DoS attacker is active. Then

where ȳa = [y a 1 , . . . , y a N ] T . Denote by n(τ, t) the number of DoS activation taking place in the interval [τ, t). To describe the intermittency features of DoS attacks, a natural characterization is given in the following two assumptions.
Assumption 3 (DoS Frequency) [11]: There exist constants η ≥ 0 and τ D > 0 such that
div.formula: n(τ, t) ≤ η + t -τ τ D .
div.p: Assumption 4 (DoS Duration) [11]: There exists a constant T ≥ 1 such that for all τ, t ≥ 0 with τ ≤ t

Remark 3: Note that Assumptions 3 and 4 are necessary for guaranteeing the controllability of the system (1) because in case τ D → 0 or T = 1, each communication attempt can be jammed by the attacker. It is equivalent to the case where the system is always in open loop. From [11] and [12], these two assumptions are reasonable which reflect the energy constraint of DoS attacks.

Remark 4: This paper focuses on the DoS attacks in a purely continuous-time setting. As stated by Persis and Tesi [11], such a problem is of importance and interest. Especially, under the continuous-time framework, slow-on-the-average DoS in a pulse form has no any impact on the closed-loop stability.

Remark 5: From (2), it is seen that the measurement data become discontinuously unavailable due to the effects of the intermittent DoS attacks. Thus the traditional adaptive backstepping control schemes [18]- [24] cannot be applied directly. It is highly desirable to develop a new adaptive control to tolerate the attack effects and unknown nonlinearities simultaneously.

div.head: C. Fuzzy Logic Systems
div.p: Fuzzy logic systems (FLSs) are introduced in [18] and [20], which can be described by the following IF-THEN rules:
div.formula: R l : If x 1 is F l 1 and • • • and x n is F l n Then y is B l , l = 1, . . . , N
div.p: which can also be formulated into the other form
div.formula: y(x) = N l=1 yl n i=1 μ F l i (x i ) N l=1 n i=1 μ F l i (x i )(3)
div.p: where yl = arg max y∈R μ l G (y). Define the fuzzy basis functions as
div.formula: ϕ l (x) = n i=1 μ F l i (x i ) N l=1 n i=1 μ F l i (x i ) . Denote θ = [y 1 , . . . , yN ] T = [θ 1 , . . . , θ N ] T and ϕ(x) = [ϕ 1 (x), . . . , ϕ N (x)]
div.p: T , then FLS (3) can be rewritten as
div.formula: y(x) = θ T ϕ(x).
div.p: Lemma 1 [20]: Let f (x) be a continuous function defined on a compact set . For any constant ε > 0, there exists an FLS (3) such that
div.formula: sup x∈ | f (x) -θ T ϕ(x)| ≤ ε.
div.p: By using Lemma 1, the unknown nonlinear functions in (1) can be approximated by
div.formula: f i,j xi,j = θ T i,j ϕ i,j xi,j + δ i,j xi,j(4)
div.p: where |δ i,j ( xi,j )| ≤ ε i,j , j = 1, . . . n i , i = 1, . . . , N. The optimal parameter vector θ i,j is defined (see [20]), satisfying θ i,j ∈ θ i,j and xi,j ∈ x i,j . Then system (1) can be further expressed as
div.formula: ẋi,j = θ T i,j ϕ i,j xi,j + δ i,j ( xi,j ) + f i,j + x i,j+1 + i,j (ȳ) ẋi,n i = θ T i,n i ϕ i,n i xi,n i + δ i,n i xi,n i + f i,n i + u i + i,n i (ȳ) y i = x i,1 , i = 1, . . . , N, j = 1, . . . , n i -1( 5 )
div.p: where
div.formula: f i,j = f i,j (x i,j )-f i,j ( xi,j ), f i,n i = f i,n i (x i,n i )-f i,n i ( xi,n i ), and |δ i,j ( xi,j )| ≤ ε i,j , |δ i,n i ( xi,n i )| ≤ ε i,n i , based on Lemma 1, with ε i,j and ε i,n i being unknown constants.
div.p: The control objective of this paper is to design an adaptive output feedback controller such that interconnected system (1) is semiglobally uniformly ultimately bounded (SUUB), and error variables converge to a sufficiently small neighborhood of the origin in the presence of the DoS attack.

div.head: III. MAIN RESULTS
div.p: In this section, we will present an estimator-based adaptive control scheme for system (1) via the backstepping design procedure. Note that the states x i,j for j = 1, . . . , n i in system (1) are unavailable for control design when a DoS attack is launched. First, a state estimator should be established. To be convenient, in the following we always denote error ˜ = -ˆ , where ˆ is the estimate of , and denote

div.head: A. Adaptive Fuzzy State Estimator Design
div.p: Similar to [17], the controller is assumed to have an embedded estimator to obtain the state in case that the measurement is missing (see Fig. 1). We introduce ϑ(t) = 1/0 as the indicator function whether the measurement signal y i (t), i.e., x i,1 (t) is received or not by the controller at time t. Based on (5), the state-space form of the estimator is designed as
div.formula: ẋi,j = θ T i,j ϕ i,j xi,j + xi,j+1 + k ϑ i,j y a i -k ϑ i,j xi,1 ẋi,n i = θ T i,n i ϕ i,n i xi,n i + u i + k ϑ i,n i y a i -k ϑ i,n i xi,1 ŷi = xi,1(6)
div.p: where
div.formula: xi,1 = x i,1 , if ϑ(t) = 1 xi,1 , otherwise.
div.p: Let e i = xi,n i -xi,n i be an estimate error. According to (2), (5), and (6), we can obtain the following estimate error system as:
div.formula: ėi = A i e i + F i + T i xi,n i ˜ i + i (ȳ) -K ϑ i e a i,1 + d i (t) (7)
div.p: where e a i,1 = y a i -xi,1 , obviously, e a i,1 = -x i,1 for t ∈ (0, +∞), and e a i,1 = e i,1 for t ∈ (0, +∞);
div.formula: d i = [d i,1 + δ i,1 ( xi,1 ), . . . , d i,n i + δ i,n i ( xi,n i )] T , F i = [ f i,1 , . . . , f i,n i ] T , i (ȳ) = [ i,1 (ȳ), . . . , i,n i (ȳ)] T , i ( xi,n i ) = diag{ϕ i,1 ( xi,1 ), . . . , ϕ i,n i ( xi,n i )} and A i = ⎡ ⎢ ⎣ 0 . . . I 0 0 . . . 0 ⎤ ⎥ ⎦, ˜ i = ⎡ ⎢ ⎣ θi,1 . . . θi,n i ⎤ ⎥ ⎦.
div.p: The vector
div.formula: K ϑ i = [k ϑ i,1 , . . . , k ϑ i,n i ]
div.p: T is the design parameter to be determined, and if the estimator receives the data x i,1 (t) at the time instant t, then
div.formula: K ϑ i = K 1 i , otherwise K ϑ i = K 0 i .
div.p: To derive the stability of the estimate error system (7), construct the Lyapunov function candidate as
div.formula: V 0 = N i=1 [e T i P ϑ i e i + ˜ i -1 i ˜ i ],
div.p: and we give the Lyapunov function analysis on the time intervals (0, t) and (0, t) in the following, respectively. First, consider the time interval (0, +∞), where ȳa = 0 from (2) and ϑ(t) = 0. The time derivative of V 0 along with ( 7) is

div.head: B. Decentralized Adaptive Control Design 1) Fuzzy Backstepping Controller Design and Lyapunov Function Analysis:
div.p: In this section, based on the above established adaptive state estimator, an output-based control law will be developed for every subsystem by employing backstepping technique. First, introduce the following coordinate transformations: (15) where z i,j is called error surface and χ i,j is called the output error of the first-order filter; α i,j-1 and ν i,j are the virtual control signal and corresponding filtered virtual control, respectively, which are defined as (16) where c i,1 , c i,2 , and c i,j are positive constants, i = 1, . . . , N, j = 3, . . . , n i ; α i,n i = u i is the control input.
div.formula: z i,1 = x i,1 , z i,j = xi,j -ν i,j χ i,j = ν i,j -α i,j-1 , i = 1, . . . , N, j = 2, . . . , n i

α i,1 = -c i,1 xi,1 -θ T i,1 ϕ i,1 xi,1 - 1 4 N k=1 h k1i xi,1 - N k=1 n i j=1 h kji xi,1 α i,2 = -c i,2 z i,2 - 1 4 z i,2 -θ T i,2 ϕ i,2 xi,2 + k ϑ i,2 e a i,1 + νi,2 α i,j = -c i,j z i,j -θ T i,j ϕ i,j xi,j + k ϑ i,j e a i,1 + νi,j -z i,j-1

2) Switching-Type Estimator Gain Design: To obtain the stability results, the estimator design parameter vectors K ϑ i , ϑ = 0, 1 are designed such that
div.formula: A T i P 0 i + P 0 i A i + 3P 0 i P 0 i + Ī1 P 0 i P 0 i Ī1 + (M i + 1)P 0 i + x2 i,1 P 0 i K 0 i K 0T i P 0 i + π i I 1 + 1 4 I 2 < αP 0 i (28
A i -K 1 i C i T P 1 i + P 1 i A i -K 1 i C i + 3P 1 i P 1 i + Ī1 P 1 i P 1 i Ī1 + (M i + 1)P 1 i + 1 4 m 2 i,1 I 1 + 1 4 I 2 < -βP 1 i (29
div.p: where α and β are positive constants.

In addition, the estimator should be stable on the time interval (0, +∞) with u i (t) = 0. The following lemma gives a sufficient condition for further constraining gain matrix K 0 i . Lemma 2: Adaptive estimator (6) with u(t) = 0 on the time interval (0, +∞) is stable with update law (12), if there exist a set of positive definite matrices P 0 i and matrices K 0 i such that
div.formula: A i -K 0 i C i T P 0 i + P 0 i A i -K 0 i C i + λ max ( i ) 2σ i Ī1 P 0 i P 0 i Ī1 < 0. (30
div.p: Proof: See the Appendix. By using Schur complement, letting 28)-( 30) can be guaranteed by the following LMIs:
div.formula: H ϑ i = P ϑ i K ϑ i , (
div.p: where
div.formula: i (t) = |x i,1 (t)|, ϒ 0 i = A T i P 0 i + P 0 i A i -αP 0 i + (M i + 1)P 0 i + π i I 1 + (1/4)I 2 and 1 i = He{P 1 i A i -H 1 i C i } + (M i + 1)P 1 i + (1/4)m 2 i,1 I 1 + (1/4)I 2 + βP 1 i .
div.p: Due to the existence of the term i (t) = |x i,1 (t)|, infinite number of LMIs need to be solved in (31). To transform the infinite number of LMIs into finite ones, motivated by Ye [34], we construct a class of "switching-type" estimators i.e., choose the estimator parameters K ϑ i , ϑ = 0, 1, as a switching type, which contains a tuning parameter [k], say
div.formula: K ϑ i = K ϑ[k] i .
div.p: To simplify the implementation of the proposed adaptive estimator and controller, we tune the parameter in a piecewise constant way.
The switching-type parameters K ϑ [k] i are obtained by Algorithm 1.
In the following stability analysis, it is shown that the turning parameter [k] will be switched only a finite number of times.

Remark 6: In [18] and [35]- [37], some switching adaptive state estimators have been constructed by using the classic ADT method. However, these estimators are designed based on perfect output measurements and thus they cannot be Algorithm 1 Design of Switching-Type Gains
Step 1: Choose positive constants ξ and < 1. Set k = 1 and t s = 0; (t s can be viewed as a memory, which memories the latest switching time.)
Step 2: By using MATLAB LMI toolbox [38], solve (32) with i (t) = kξ + i (0), and let
div.formula: K 0[k] i = (P 0 i ) -1 H 0 i and K 1[k] i = (P 1 i ) -1 H 1 i ; Step 3: At each time t > t s , if i (t) > i (t s ) + ξ then k = k+1 and t s = t, turn to Step 2. Else t s = t, K 0 i = K 0[k] i and K 1 i = K 1[k] i .
div.p: applied to our case since the sensor measurements are corrupted intermittently by the DoS attackers. By comparison, in our proposed scheme, the switching-type adaptive estimator is designed by developing the technique of switching control between stable and unstable uncertain nonlinear subsystems. The estimator gain K ϑ i increases in a switching way until estimate error system is stable. However, such a design method may cause a big control energy and increase of computational efforts.

div.head: C. Stability Analysis
div.p: Inspired by the concept of ADT [33], combining the above analysis result ( 26) and ( 27) of the Lyapunov function, the stability of closed-loop system, which switches between stable and unstable subsystem, can be established. First, the following assumption is required, which represents the concept of semiglobal. It means that all the closed-loop initial conditions are bounded.

Assumption 5 [39]: For a given p > 0, there exists V(0) ≤ p. Theorem 1: Consider system (1) under the intermittent DoS attack. Under Assumptions 1-5, if there exist a set of positive definite matrices P 0 i , P 1 i , matrices H 0 i , H 1 i , and positive constants c i,1 and λ * such that (31) with i (t) = kξ + i (0) in Algorithm 1
div.formula: P 0 i < μP 1 i , P 1 i < μP 0 i 2 n(N+1)-1 4 + 7 + N 16 - c i,1 2 -α * P 0 i e i1 -I < 0 -2(c i,1 -7) < -β, β -λ * β + α > 1 T , λ * > log μ τ D (32
div.p: and choose c i,j > β, (1/[τ i,j ]) -N 2 i,j -(1/4) > β and (σ i /[λ max ( i )]) > (9/4) + β, i = 1, . . . , N, j = 2, . . . , n i , then the proposed adaptive decentralized control scheme consisting of the adaptive estimator (6) with update law (12), the virtual control and control law ( 16) and (17) can ensure that all the signals in the closed-loop system remain SUUB. Moreover, all the error variables e i,j , z i,j and χ i,k , j = 1, . . . , n i , k = 2, . . . , n i , i = 1, . . . , N may be made small arbitrarily by suitably adjusting the design parameters.
Proof: Under the condition (32), from ( 26) and ( 27), it follows that:
div.formula: V ≤ λ(t)V + C (33
div.p: where λ(t) = α when t ∈ (0, +∞), and λ(t) = -β when t ∈ (0, +∞), C = N i=1 λ i . Recall that t j , represents the time instant of DoS off/on transition. For t ∈ [t j , t j+1 ), denote λ(t) = λ j . Then one has
div.formula: V(t) ≤ e λ j (t-t j ) V t + j + C t t j e λ j (t-τ ) dτ ≤ μe λ j (t-t j ) V t - j + C t t j e λ j (t-τ ) dτ.
div.p: By the recursive method for time j, one has V(t) ≤ μ n(0,t) e λ j (t-t j )+λ j-1( t j -t j-1) +•••+λ 0 (t 1 -0) V(0)
div.formula: + C t 1 0 μ n(t 1 ,t) e λ j (t-t j )+λ j-1( t j -t j-1) +•••+λ 0 (t 1 -τ ) dτ + C t 2 t 1 μ n(t 2 ,t) e λ j (t-t j )+λ j-1 (t j -t j-1 )+•••+λ 0 (t 2 -τ ) dτ + • • • + C t t j e λ j (t-τ ) dτ.
div.p: According to Assumption 4, on the time interval [τ, t],
div.formula: | (τ, t)| ≤ (t -τ/T) and | (τ, t)| ≥ (1 -(1/T))(t -τ ), then we have V(t) ≤ μ n(0,t) e -[β| (0,t)|-α| (0,t)|] V(0) + C t 1 0 μ n(t 1 ,t) e -[β| (τ,t)|-α| (τ,t)|] dτ + C t 2 t 1 μ n(t 2 ,t) e -[β| (τ,t)|-α| (τ,t)|] dτ + • • • + C t t j e -[β| (τ,t)|-α| (τ,t)|] dτ ≤ μ n(0,t) e -[β| (0,t)|-α| (0,t)|] V(0) + C t 0 μ n(τ,t) e -[β| (τ,t)|-α| (τ,t)|] dτ ≤ e -[β| (0,t)|-α| (0,t)|-n(0,t) log μ] V(0) + C t 0 e -[β| (τ,t)|-α| (τ,t)|-n(τ,t) log μ] dτ. Since [(β -λ * )/(β + α)] > (1/T), n(τ, t) < η + (t -τ )/τ D and τ D > log μ/λ * , then there exists a constant δ > 0 such that β| (τ, t)| -α| (τ, t)| > λ * (t -τ ) > (n(τ, t) -η) log μ + δ(t -τ ).
div.p: Thus, it follows that:
div.formula: V(t) ≤ μ η e -δt V(0) + C t 0 e -δ(t-τ ) dτ ≤ μ η e -δt V(0) + C δ . (34
div.p: It is also obtained that V(t) ≤ -δV(t) + C, which implies V(t) < 0 on V(t) = p when δ > C/p. Therefore, V(t) ≤ p is an invariant set, i.e., if V(0) ≤ p, then V(t) ≤ p for all t > 0. By following the same argument in the stability analysis used in [39]

Remark 7: Similar to [11] and [12], the stability analysis is mainly divided into two steps. First, by Lyapunov function analysis and controller design, the exponential decay rate β and exponential divergence rate α of state trajectory can be obtained on the attack-sleeping time interval and attack-active time interval, respectively. Second, an improved ADT method is derived by considering frequency and duration properties of DoS attacks (Assumptions 3 and 4). Note that the Lyapunov function analysis on stable and unstable intervals may be more complex compared with ones in [11], [12], and [33] due to the nonlinear uncertainties and interconnections. The improved ADT method is also more flexible and more applicable due to the introduction of switched Lyapunov function.

Remark 8: The control performance of system (1) or tolerance capacity for DoS attacks can be improved through increasing k i,j and c i,j or decreasing τ i,j . However, if k i,j and c i,j are too big or τ i,j are too small, the control energy is also big. On the other hand, for a given controller, a small T or τ D also leads to a degradation of system performance. Therefore, the proposed control scheme is flexible enough for designers to choose design parameters that can be used for tradeoff among control performance, DoS tolerance capability and control energy.

Remark 9: When T is a small constant more than 1, it implies that the attack-active time interval is significantly longer than the attack-sleeping one. Although the attack tolerance capacity can be improved by increasing β, the condition (32) may also become infeasible for a big β due to the constraints of multiple matrix inequalities. Also, from (32), some variables are interlaced together such that the parameters should be carefully chosen in the controller design.

div.head: IV. SIMULATION EXAMPLE
div.p: In the simulation, we will consider a power network system [6], [40], which is composed of two interconnected synchronous generators described by
div.formula: δi = ω i ωi = D i 2H i ω i + ω 0 2H i ( P mi + P ei ) Ṗmi = 1 T i (-P mi -k i ω i + u i + d i (t)) (35
div.p: where i = 1, 2, for the ith network generator and δ i , ω i , P mi , and P ei are the deviations of rotor angle, relative rotor speed, mechanical input power, and active power, respectively. d i (t) is the external disturbance. The control signal u i is the deviation of the valve opening. H i , D i , ω 0 , k i , and T i are constant system parameters. Note that ω 0 and k i are unknown for designers. The active power P ei is defined as
div.formula: P e1 = - E 1 E 2 X [sin(δ 1 -δ 2 ) -sin(δ 10 -δ 20 )] P e2 = -P e1
div.p: where δ 10 and δ 20 are the steady state angles of the first and second generators and E 1 and E 2 are two constants. The monitor measures directly the rotor angle of the each generator as y i = δ i (t), i = 1, 2. The adversary launches an intermittent DoS attack with τ D = 3.2 and T = 5. The external disturbances are set as d 1 (t) = sin t and d 2 (0) = 0. Choose the state variables as [x i,1 , x i,2 , x i,3 ] = [ δ i , ω i , (ω 0 /2H i ) P mi ], and the equivalent control input is v i = (D i /[2H i T i ])u i . Then the system (35) can be transformed into the strict-feedback form as (1).

In the simulation, the system parameters are specified as To further show the advantage of the proposed secure adaptive control (SAC), the traditional adaptive control (TAC) scheme based on [20] is also applied to system (34), where α
div.formula: i,1 = -c i,1 y a i -θ T i,1 ϕ i,1 (y a i ) -(1/4) N k=1 h k1i (y a i ) - N k=1
div.p: n j=1 h kji (y a i ), and α i,2 and u i are the same as (16). Choose c i,1 = 3, c i,2 = 7, c i,3 = 15, and τ i,2 = τ i,3 = 0.1, i = 1, 2 and by solving the inequality result in unstable closed-loop systems, but the secure control problem of the resulting closed-loop system (6), ( 16), (17), and ( 35) is solvable by applying the proposed decentralized SAC scheme. However, the system performance has to be degraded due to the effects of the DoS attacks. From Figs. 6 and7, it can be seen that compared with the TAC and PPC schemes, the SAC scheme requires a bigger control gain (about four times the sizes of those of the other two methods) before IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON CYBERNETICS the DoS attack occurs. In addition, to assess the observation performance of the switching-type state estimator, the state estimate errors are also plotted in Figs. 8 and9, which show that good observation performance has been achieved. In [13] and [14], some resilient control schemes are proposed for nonlinear systems under similar DoS attacks, whereas these control strategies are restricted to the case of static state feedback which requires full state information. Although an output-based dynamic control scheme is presented in [12], it requires the exact knowledge of system models. Therefore, these schemes are no longer effective to address system (35) that contains unmeasured system states, unknown parameters ω 0 and k i and uncertain interconnection term P ei .
div.formula: (A i -K i C i ) T P i + P i (A i -K i C i ) + 2P i P i + Ī1 P i P i Ī1 + (M i + 1)P i + 1 4 m 2 i,1 I 1 +1
div.p: On the other hand, to verify the effects of frequency and duration of DoS attacks, we select T = 3.12 and τ D = 4.03. Then one can obtain λ * > 1.9884 and λ * < 1.28, and obviously λ * does not exist (does not satisfy the condition of Theorem 1). For this case, we apply the SAC scheme to (35) with the same parameters as the aforementioned those, the corresponding state trajectories are given in Figs. 10111213and indicate that the adaptive control system is unstable.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, a novel decentralized adaptive secure control scheme has been developed for a class of nonlinear interconnected CPSs subject to intermittent DoS attacks and external disturbances. A switching-type state estimator has been constructed to obtain the system state by using discontinuous output measurement. Based on the Lyapunov theory and improved ADT method, the stability analysis can be established regardless of DoS attacks. Future investigation should include more general nonlinear systems with more inputs and the case with measurement noise on the basis of the results of this paper. APPENDIX PROOF OF LEMMA 2 Rewrite (6) with u(t) = 0 on the interval (0, +∞) into the following form:
div.formula: ẋi = A i -K 0 i C i xi + T i xi,n i ˆ i . (36
div.p: Construct the Lyapunov function as V i = xT i P 0 i xi + ˆ T i -1 i ˆ i . Its derivative along with ( 12) and ( 35) can be computed by
div.formula: Vi = 2x T i P i (A i -K i C i )x i + 2x T i P 0 i T i xi,n i ˆ i + 2 ˆ T i -1 i -i i xi,n i P 0 i I 1 xi -σ i ˆ i = 2x T i P i (A i -K i C i )x i + xT i Ī1 P 0 i T i xi,n i ˆ i -2σ i ˆ T i -1 i ˆ i .
div.p: It is obtained from Young's inequality that
div.formula: Vi ≤ xT i A i -K 0 i C i T P 0 i + P 0 i A i -K 0 i C i + λ max ( i ) 2σ i Ī1 P 0 i P 0 i Ī1 xi .
div.p: Therefore, condition (30) ensures that there exists a small constant > 0 such that Vi ≤ -xi 2 . Using Barbalat's lemma, the stability of the estimator can be achieved.
